title: Snowden Revelations and Suing the NSA
author: marsresident / Van Kush Family
overview: Comprehensive guide to NSA surveillance programs, FOIA requests, privacy laws, and legal resources for protecting civil liberties

prism_program.definition: NSA program using Google, Facebook, Yahoo servers to collect information

foia_requests.purpose: Get records about YOU from the NSA
foia_requests.recommendation: Can file BOTH FOIA and Privacy Act requests

ecpa.name: Electronic Communications Privacy Act
ecpa.criminal_penalties: Up to 5 years prison, fines up to $250,000
ecpa.civil_remedies: Actual damages, punitive damages, attorney's fees

criminal_charges_officers.purpose: Criminal charges for government officers using status to infringe rights

tax_misuse.holding: You can sue the Government for misuse of tax funds

wiretapping.case: United States v. United States District Court

government_conspiracy_example.description: Extensive Government Conspiracy hashed out in Court for 20 years

thermal_imaging.holding: Thermal imaging (FLIR) from public vantage point to monitor home radiation is a 'search' requiring warrant

quiz_questions.a: NSA program using Google, Facebook, Yahoo servers to collect information about users
quiz_questions.explanation: Revealed by Snowden - mass surveillance infrastructure

quiz_questions.q: What is the difference between FOIA and Privacy Act requests?
quiz_questions.a: Privacy Act is standard for personal records; FOIA is broader but both can be filed
quiz_questions.explanation: Privacy Act specifically for records about YOU

quiz_questions.q: What penalties exist for ECPA violations?
quiz_questions.a: Up to 5 years prison, $250,000 fines, plus civil damages and attorney fees
quiz_questions.explanation: Both criminal and civil remedies available

quiz_questions.q: Which case established you can sue government for tax misuse?
quiz_questions.explanation: Taxpayer standing to challenge government spending

quiz_questions.q: What did Kyllo v. United States establish about thermal imaging?
quiz_questions.a: Using FLIR to monitor home heat radiation is a 'search' requiring a warrant
quiz_questions.explanation: Technology doesn't eliminate Fourth Amendment protections
